body:
I can reproduce this. It seems that when the configs are normalized, the logic to exclude predefined and global `ignores` configs from being modified will only check for a missing `files` property in a config:

https://github.com/eslint/eslint/blob/c2cf85a7447777e6b499cbb5c49de919bb5c817f/lib/config/flat-config-array.js#L145-L146

To be consistent, I think this should check that no other properties than `ignores` and `name` are present.

This is intentional. A config object with `ignores` and `rules` is not ignoring files, it's excluding files from applying the following rules ([docs](https://eslint.org/docs/latest/use/configure/configuration-files#excluding-files-with-ignores). As such, `--no-ignore` doesn't apply because this config object isn't forcing any files to be ignored.

So the current behavior isn't intentional? Because currently `--no-ignore` applies to an object that has only `ignores` and `rules` by removing its `ignores` and thus making it an object that matches all files.

Ah sorry, I think I read this too fast initially.

The intent is that `--no-ignore` applies only to global ignores (an object with `ignores` only) and not for exclusions (an object with `ignores` and `rules`), so I agree that this is a bug.

issue.title: fix: `--no-ignore` should not apply to non-global ignores

Fixes #18261

#### What changes did you make? (Give an overview)

Updated condition for whether `ignore:false` (`--no-ignore`) should apply to a config object to check if the object has any other keys (excluding `name`) instead of just checking if it has the `files` key.

issue.title: fix: allow `name` in global ignores, fix `--no-ignore` for non-global
